title: Sedimentary rock
text:
Sedimentary rocks are types of <a href="rock%20%28geology%29">rock</a> that are formed by the accumulation or deposition of <a href="mineral">mineral</a> or <a href="organic%20matter">organic</a> particles at <a href="Earth%23Surface">Earth's surface</a>, followed by <a href="cementation%20%28geology%29">cementation</a>. <a href="Sedimentation">Sedimentation</a> is the collective name for processes that cause these particles to settle in place. The particles that form a sedimentary rock are called <a href="sediment">sediment</a>, and may be composed of <a href="detritus%20%28geology%29">geological detritus</a> (minerals) or <a href="detritus">biological detritus</a> (organic matter). The geological detritus originated from <a href="weathering">weathering</a> and <a href="erosion">erosion</a> of existing rocks, or from the solidification of molten lava blobs erupted by volcanoes. The geological detritus is transported to the place of deposition by water, wind, ice or <a href="Mass%20wasting">mass movement</a>, which are called agents of <a href="denudation">denudation</a>. Biological detritus was formed by bodies and parts (mainly shells) of dead aquatic organisms, as well as their fecal mass, suspended in water and slowly piling up on the floor of water bodies (<a href="marine%20snow">marine snow</a>). Sedimentation may also occur as dissolved minerals precipitate from <a href="aqueous%20solution">water solution</a>.
The sedimentary rock cover of the continents of the <a href="Crust%20%28geology%29">Earth's crust</a> is extensive (73% of the Earth's current land surface), but sedimentary rock is estimated to be only 8% of the volume of the crust. Sedimentary rocks are only a thin veneer over a crust consisting mainly of <a href="igneous%20rock">igneous</a> and <a href="metamorphic%20rock">metamorphic rock</a>s. Sedimentary rocks are deposited in layers as <a href="stratum">strata</a>, forming a structure called <a href="bed%20%28geology%29">bedding</a>. Sedimentary rocks are often deposited in large structures called <a href="sedimentary%20basin">sedimentary basin</a>s. Sedimentary rocks have also been found on <a href="Mars">Mars</a>.
The study of sedimentary rocks and rock strata provides information about the subsurface that is useful for <a href="civil%20engineering">civil engineering</a>, for example in the construction of <a href="road">road</a>s, <a href="house">house</a>s, <a href="tunnel">tunnel</a>s, <a href="canal">canal</a>s or other structures. Sedimentary rocks are also important sources of <a href="natural%20resource">natural resource</a>s including <a href="coal">coal</a>, <a href="fossil%20fuel">fossil fuel</a>s, <a href="drinking%20water">drinking water</a> and <a href="ore">ore</a>s.
The study of the sequence of sedimentary rock strata is the main source for an understanding of the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Earth">Earth's history</a>, including <a href="palaeogeography">palaeogeography</a>, <a href="paleoclimatology">paleoclimatology</a> and the <a href="Evolutionary%20history%20of%20life">history of life</a>. The <a href="List%20of%20academic%20disciplines">scientific discipline</a> that studies the properties and origin of sedimentary rocks is called <a href="sedimentology">sedimentology</a>. Sedimentology is part of both <a href="geology">geology</a> and <a href="physical%20geography">physical geography</a> and overlaps partly with other disciplines in the <a href="Earth%20science">Earth science</a>s, such as <a href="Pedology%20%28soil%20study%29">pedology</a>, <a href="geomorphology">geomorphology</a>, <a href="geochemistry">geochemistry</a> and <a href="structural%20geology">structural geology</a>.
Classification based on origin.
Sedimentary rocks can be subdivided into four groups based on the processes responsible for their formation: clastic sedimentary rocks, biochemical (biogenic) sedimentary rocks, chemical sedimentary rocks, and a fourth category for "other" sedimentary rocks formed by impacts, <a href="volcanism">volcanism</a>, and other minor processes.
Clastic sedimentary rocks.
Clastic sedimentary rocks are composed of rock fragments ("clasts") that have been cemented together. The clasts are commonly individual grains of <a href="quartz">quartz</a>, <a href="feldspar">feldspar</a>, <a href="clay%20minerals">clay minerals</a>, or <a href="mica">mica</a>. However, any type of mineral may be present. Clasts may also be "lithic fragments" composed of more than one mineral.
Clastic sedimentary rocks are subdivided according to the dominant particle size. Most geologists use the <a href="Particle%20size%20%28grain%20size%29%23Wentworth">Udden-Wentworth</a> grain size scale and divide unconsolidated sediment into three fractions: <a href="gravel">gravel</a> (>2 mm diameter), <a href="sand">sand</a> (1/16 to 2 mm diameter), and <a href="mud">mud</a> (<1/16 mm diameter). Mud is further divided into <a href="silt">silt</a> (1/16 to 1/256 mm diameter) and <a href="clay">clay</a> (<1/256 mm diameter). The classification of clastic sedimentary rocks parallels this scheme; <a href="Conglomerate%20%28geology%29">conglomerates</a> and <a href="breccia">breccia</a>s are made mostly of <a href="gravel">gravel</a>, <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>s are made mostly of <a href="sand">sand</a>, and <a href="mudrock">mudrock</a>s are made mostly of mud. This tripartite subdivision is mirrored by the broad categories of <a href="rudite">rudite</a>s, <a href="arenite">arenite</a>s, and <a href="lutite">lutite</a>s, respectively, in older literature.
The subdivision of these three broad categories is based on differences in clast shape (<a href="conglomerate%20%28geology%29">conglomerates</a> and <a href="breccia">breccia</a>s), composition (<a href="sandstone">sandstone</a>s), or grain size or texture (<a href="mudrock">mudrock</a>s).
Conglomerates and breccias.
Conglomerates are dominantly composed of rounded <a href="gravel">gravel</a>, while <a href="breccia">breccia</a>s are composed of dominantly angular <a href="gravel">gravel</a>.
Sandstones.
Sandstone classification schemes vary widely, but most geologists have adopted the Dott scheme, which uses the relative abundance of quartz, feldspar, and lithic framework grains and the abundance of a muddy matrix between the larger grains.
Six <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> names are possible using the descriptors for grain composition (quartz-, feldspathic-, and lithic-) and the amount of matrix (wacke or arenite). For example, a quartz arenite would be composed of mostly (>90%) quartz grains and have little or no clayey matrix between the grains, a lithic wacke would have abundant lithic grains and abundant muddy matrix, etc.
Although the Dott classification scheme is widely used by sedimentologists, common names like <a href="greywacke">greywacke</a>, <a href="arkose">arkose</a>, and quartz sandstone are still widely used by non-specialists and in popular literature.
Mudrocks.
Mudrocks are sedimentary rocks composed of at least 50% <a href="silt">silt</a>- and <a href="clay">clay</a>-sized particles. These relatively fine-grained particles are commonly transported by <a href="turbulence">turbulent flow</a> in water or air, and deposited as the flow calms and the particles settle out of <a href="Suspension%20%28chemistry%29">suspension</a>.
Most authors presently use the term "mudrock" to refer to all rocks composed dominantly of mud. Mudrocks can be divided into siltstones, composed dominantly of silt-sized particles; mudstones with subequal mixture of silt- and clay-sized particles; and claystones, composed mostly of clay-sized particles. Most authors use "<a href="shale">shale</a>" as a term for a <a href="Fissility%20%28geology%29">fissile</a> mudrock (regardless of grain size) although some older literature uses the term "shale" as a synonym for mudrock.

Chemical sedimentary rocks.
Chemical sedimentary rock forms when mineral constituents in <a href="Solution%20%28chemistry%29">solution</a> become <a href="supersaturation">supersaturated</a> and inorganically <a href="precipitate">precipitate</a>. Common chemical sedimentary rocks include <a href="Oolite">oolitic limestone</a> and rocks composed of <a href="evaporite">evaporite</a> minerals, such as <a href="halite">halite</a> (rock salt), <a href="sylvite">sylvite</a>, <a href="baryte">baryte</a> and <a href="gypsum">gypsum</a>.
Other sedimentary rocks.
This fourth miscellaneous category includes volcanic <a href="tuff">tuff</a> and <a href="Breccia%23Volcanic">volcanic breccias</a> formed by deposition and later cementation of lava fragments erupted by volcanoes, and <a href="Breccia%23Impact">impact breccias</a> formed after <a href="impact%20events">impact events</a>.
Classification based on composition.
Alternatively, sedimentary rocks can be subdivided into compositional groups based on their mineralogy:
Deposition and transformation.
Sediment transport and deposition.
Sedimentary <a href="rock%20%28geology%29">rocks</a> are formed when <a href="sediment">sediment</a> is <a href="deposition%20%28geology%29">deposited</a> out of air, ice, wind, gravity, or water flows carrying the particles in <a href="Suspension%20%28chemistry%29">suspension</a>. This sediment is often formed when <a href="weathering">weathering</a> and <a href="erosion">erosion</a> break down a rock into loose material in a source area. The material is then <a href="Sediment%20transport">transported</a> from the source area to the deposition area. The type of sediment transported depends on the geology of the <a href="hinterland">hinterland</a> (the source area of the sediment). However, some sedimentary rocks, such as <a href="evaporite">evaporite</a>s, are composed of material that form at the place of deposition. The nature of a sedimentary rock, therefore, not only depends on the sediment supply, but also on the <a href="sedimentary%20depositional%20environment">sedimentary depositional environment</a> in which it formed.
Transformation (Diagenesis).
As sediments accumulate in a depositional environment, older sediments are buried by younger sediments, and they undergo diagenesis. Diagenesis includes all the chemical, physical, and biological changes, exclusive of surface weathering, undergone by a sediment after its initial deposition. This includes <a href="compaction%20%28geology%29">compaction</a> and <a href="lithification">lithification</a> of the sediments. Early stages of diagenesis, described as "eogenesis", take place at shallow depths (a few tens of meters) and is characterized by <a href="bioturbation">bioturbation</a> and mineralogical changes in the sediments, with only slight compaction. The red <a href="hematite">hematite</a> that gives <a href="red%20beds">red bed</a> sandstones their color is likely formed during eogenesis. Some <a href="biochemistry">biochemical</a> processes, like the activity of <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a>, can affect minerals in a rock and are therefore seen as part of diagenesis.
Deeper burial is accompanied by "mesogenesis", during which most of the compaction and lithification takes place. Compaction takes place as the sediments come under increasing <a href="overburden%20pressure">overburden (lithostatic) pressure</a> from overlying sediments. Sediment grains move into more compact arrangements, grains of ductile minerals (such as <a href="mica">mica</a>) are deformed, and pore space is reduced. Sediments are typically saturated with <a href="groundwater">groundwater</a> or seawater when originally deposited, and as pore space is reduced, much of these <a href="connate%20fluids">connate fluids</a> are expelled. In addition to this physical compaction, chemical compaction may take place via <a href="pressure%20solution">pressure solution</a>. Points of contact between grains are under the greatest strain, and the strained mineral is more soluble than the rest of the grain. As a result, the contact points are dissolved away, allowing the grains to come into closer contact. The increased pressure and temperature stimulate further chemical reactions, such as the reactions by which <a href="organic%20material">organic material</a> becomes <a href="lignite">lignite</a> or <a href="coal">coal</a>.
Lithification follows closely on compaction, as increased temperatures at depth hasten the <a href="precipitation%20%28chemistry%29">precipitation</a> of cement that binds the grains together. Pressure solution contributes to this process of <a href="cementation%20%28geology%29">cementation</a>, as the mineral dissolved from strained contact points is redeposited in the unstrained pore spaces. This further reduces porosity and makes the rock more compact and <a href="Competence%20%28geology%29">competent</a>.
Unroofing of buried sedimentary rock is accompanied by "telogenesis", the third and final stage of diagenesis. As erosion reduces the depth of burial, renewed exposure to <a href="meteoric%20water">meteoric water</a> produces additional changes to the sedimentary rock, such as <a href="Leaching%20%28chemical%20science%29">leaching</a> of some of the cement to produce <a href="secondary%20porosity">secondary porosity</a>.
At sufficiently high temperature and pressure, the realm of diagenesis makes way for <a href="metamorphism">metamorphism</a>, the process that forms <a href="metamorphic%20rock">metamorphic rock</a>.
Properties.
Color.
The color of a sedimentary rock is often mostly determined by <a href="iron">iron</a>, an element with two major oxides: <a href="iron%28II%29%20oxide">iron(II) oxide</a> and <a href="iron%28III%29%20oxide">iron(III) oxide</a>. Iron(II) oxide (FeO) only forms under low oxygen (<a href="Anoxic%20waters">anoxic</a>) circumstances and gives the rock a grey or greenish colour. Iron(III) oxide (Fe2O3) in a richer oxygen environment is often found in the form of the mineral <a href="hematite">hematite</a> and gives the rock a reddish to brownish colour. In arid continental climates rocks are in direct contact with the atmosphere, and oxidation is an important process, giving the rock a red or orange colour. Thick sequences of red sedimentary rocks formed in arid climates are called <a href="red%20beds">red beds</a>. However, a red colour does not necessarily mean the rock formed in a continental environment or arid climate.
The presence of organic material can colour a rock black or grey. Organic material is formed from dead organisms, mostly plants. Normally, such material eventually <a href="decomposition">decays</a> by oxidation or bacterial activity. Under anoxic circumstances, however, organic material cannot decay and leaves a dark sediment, rich in organic material. This can, for example, occur at the bottom of deep seas and lakes. There is little water mixing in such environments; as a result, oxygen from surface water is not brought down, and the deposited sediment is normally a fine dark clay. Dark rocks, rich in organic material, are therefore often <a href="shale">shale</a>s.
Texture.
The <a href="grain%20size">size</a>, form and orientation of clasts (the original pieces of rock) in a sediment is called its <a href="texture%20%28geology%29">texture</a>. The texture is a small-scale property of a rock, but determines many of its large-scale properties, such as the <a href="density">density</a>, <a href="porosity">porosity</a> or <a href="Permeability%20%28earth%20sciences%29">permeability</a>.
The 3D orientation of the clasts is called the <a href="fabric">fabric</a> of the rock. The size and form of clasts can be used to determine the velocity and direction of <a href="current%20%28stream%29">current</a> in the sedimentary environment that moved the clasts from their origin; fine, <a href="calcareous%20mud">calcareous mud</a> only settles in quiet water while gravel and larger clasts are moved only by rapidly moving water. The grain size of a rock is usually expressed with the Wentworth scale, though alternative scales are sometimes used. The grain size can be expressed as a diameter or a volume, and is always an average value, since a rock is composed of clasts with different sizes. The <a href="Distribution%20%28mathematics%29">statistical distribution</a> of grain sizes is different for different rock types and is described in a property called the <a href="sorting%20%28sediment%29">sorting</a> of the rock. When all clasts are more or less of the same size, the rock is called 'well-sorted', and when there is a large spread in grain size, the rock is called 'poorly sorted'.
The form of the clasts can reflect the origin of the rock. For example, <a href="coquina">coquina</a>, a rock composed of clasts of broken shells, can only form in energetic water. The form of a clast can be described by using four parameters:
Chemical sedimentary rocks have a non-clastic texture, consisting entirely of crystals. To describe such a texture, only the average size of the crystals and the fabric are necessary.
Mineralogy.
Most sedimentary rocks contain either <a href="quartz">quartz</a> (<a href="siliciclastic">siliciclastic</a> rocks) or <a href="calcite">calcite</a> (<a href="carbonate%20rock">carbonate rock</a>s). In contrast to igneous and metamorphic rocks, a sedimentary rock usually contains very few different major minerals. However, the origin of the minerals in a sedimentary rock is often more complex than in an igneous rock. Minerals in a sedimentary rock may have been present in the original sediments or may formed by precipitation during diagenesis. In the second case, a mineral precipitate may have grown over an older generation of cement. A complex diagenetic history can be established by <a href="optical%20mineralogy">optical mineralogy</a>, using a <a href="petrographic%20microscope">petrographic microscope</a>.
Carbonate rocks predominantly consist of <a href="carbonate">carbonate</a> minerals such as <a href="calcite">calcite</a>, <a href="aragonite">aragonite</a> or <a href="Dolomite%20%28mineral%29">dolomite</a>. Both the cement and the clasts (including fossils and <a href="ooid">ooid</a>s) of a carbonate sedimentary rock usually consist of carbonate minerals. The mineralogy of a clastic rock is determined by the material supplied by the source area, the manner of its transport to the place of deposition and the stability of that particular mineral.
The resistance of rock-forming minerals to weathering is expressed by the <a href="Goldich%20dissolution%20series">Goldich dissolution series</a>. In this series, quartz is the most stable, followed by <a href="feldspar">feldspar</a>, <a href="mica">mica</a>s, and finally other less stable minerals that are only present when little weathering has occurred. The amount of weathering depends mainly on the distance to the source area, the local climate and the time it took for the sediment to be transported to the point where it is deposited. In most sedimentary rocks, mica, feldspar and less stable minerals have been weathered to <a href="clay%20minerals">clay minerals</a> like <a href="kaolinite">kaolinite</a>, <a href="illite">illite</a> or <a href="smectite">smectite</a>.
Fossils.
Among the three major types of rock, fossils are most commonly found in sedimentary rock. Unlike most igneous and metamorphic rocks, sedimentary rocks form at temperatures and pressures that do not destroy fossil remnants. Often these fossils may only be visible under <a href="microscope">magnification</a>.
Dead organisms in nature are usually quickly removed by <a href="scavenger">scavenger</a>s, <a href="bacteria">bacteria</a>, <a href="Decomposition">rotting</a> and erosion, but under exceptional circumstances, these natural processes are unable to take place, leading to fossilisation. The chance of fossilisation is higher when the sedimentation rate is high (so that a carcass is quickly buried), in <a href="Hypoxia%20%28environmental%29">anoxic</a> environments (where little bacterial activity occurs) or when the organism had a particularly hard skeleton. Larger, well-preserved fossils are relatively rare.
Fossils can be both the direct remains or imprints of organisms and their skeletons. Most commonly preserved are the harder parts of organisms such as bones, shells, and the woody <a href="tissue%20%28biology%29">tissue</a> of plants. Soft tissue has a much smaller chance of being fossilized, and the preservation of soft tissue of animals older than 40 million years is very rare. Imprints of organisms made while they were still alive are called <a href="trace%20fossil">trace fossil</a>s, examples of which are <a href="burrow">burrow</a>s, <a href="footprint">footprint</a>s, etc.
As a part of a sedimentary rock, fossils undergo the same <a href="diagenesis">diagenetic processes</a> as does the host rock. For example, a shell consisting of calcite can dissolve while a cement of silica then fills the cavity. In the same way, precipitating minerals can fill cavities formerly occupied by <a href="blood%20vessel">blood vessel</a>s, <a href="vascular%20tissue">vascular tissue</a> or other soft tissues. This preserves the form of the organism but changes the chemical composition, a process called <a href="permineralization">permineralization</a>. The most common minerals involved in permineralization are various forms of <a href="amorphous%20silica">amorphous silica</a> (<a href="chalcedony">chalcedony</a>, <a href="flint">flint</a>, <a href="chert">chert</a>), <a href="carbonate">carbonate</a>s (especially calcite), and <a href="pyrite">pyrite</a>.
At high pressure and temperature, the <a href="organic%20material">organic material</a> of a dead organism undergoes chemical reactions in which <a href="Volatiles%23Igneous%20petrology">volatiles</a> such as <a href="water">water</a> and <a href="carbon%20dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> are expulsed. The fossil, in the end, consists of a thin layer of pure carbon or its mineralized form, <a href="graphite">graphite</a>. This form of fossilisation is called <a href="carbonisation">carbonisation</a>. It is particularly important for plant fossils. The same process is responsible for the formation of <a href="fossil%20fuel">fossil fuel</a>s like <a href="lignite">lignite</a> or <a href="coal">coal</a>.
Primary sedimentary structures.
Structures in sedimentary rocks can be divided into "primary" structures (formed during deposition) and "secondary" structures (formed after deposition). Unlike textures, structures are always large-scale features that can easily be studied in the field. <a href="Sedimentary%20structures">Sedimentary structures</a> can indicate something about the sedimentary environment or can serve to tell <a href="way%20up%20structure">which side originally faced up</a> where tectonics have tilted or overturned sedimentary layers.
Sedimentary rocks are laid down in layers called <a href="Bed%20%28geology%29">beds</a> or <a href="Stratum">strata</a>. A bed is defined as a layer of rock that has a uniform <a href="lithology">lithology</a> and texture. Beds form by the deposition of layers of sediment on top of each other. The sequence of beds that characterizes sedimentary rocks is called <a href="bed%20%28geology%29">bedding</a>. Single beds can be a couple of centimetres to several meters thick. Finer, less pronounced layers are called laminae, and the structure a lamina forms in a rock is called <a href="lamination%20%28geology%29">lamination</a>. Laminae are usually less than a few centimetres thick. Though bedding and lamination are often originally horizontal in nature, this is not always the case. In some environments, beds are deposited at a (usually small) angle. Sometimes multiple sets of layers with different orientations exist in the same rock, a structure called <a href="cross-bedding">cross-bedding</a>. Cross-bedding is characteristic of deposition by a flowing medium (wind or water).
The opposite of cross-bedding is parallel lamination, where all sedimentary layering is parallel. Differences in laminations are generally caused by cyclic changes in the sediment supply, caused, for example, by seasonal changes in rainfall, temperature or biochemical activity. Laminae that represent seasonal changes (similar to <a href="tree%20ring">tree ring</a>s) are called <a href="varve">varve</a>s. Any sedimentary rock composed of millimeter or finer scale layers can be named with the general term "laminite". When sedimentary rocks have no lamination at all, their structural character is called massive bedding.
<a href="Graded%20bedding">Graded bedding</a> is a structure where beds with a smaller grain size occur on top of beds with larger grains. This structure forms when fast flowing water stops flowing. Larger, heavier clasts in suspension settle first, then smaller clasts. Although graded bedding can form in many different environments, it is a characteristic of <a href="turbidity%20current">turbidity current</a>s.
The surface of a particular bed, called the <a href="bedform">bedform</a>, can also be indicative of a particular sedimentary environment. Examples of bed forms include <a href="dune">dune</a>s and <a href="ripple%20marks">ripple marks</a>. Sole markings, such as tool marks and flute casts, are grooves eroded on a surface that are preserved by renewed sedimentation. These are often elongated structures and can be used to establish the direction of the flow during deposition.
Ripple marks also form in flowing water. There can be symmetric or asymmetric. Asymmetric ripples form in environments where the current is in one direction, such as rivers. The longer flank of such ripples is on the upstream side of the current. Symmetric wave ripples occur in environments where currents reverse directions, such as tidal flats.
<a href="Mudcrack">Mudcrack</a>s are a bed form caused by the dehydration of sediment that occasionally comes above the water surface. Such structures are commonly found at tidal flats or <a href="point%20bar">point bar</a>s along rivers.
Secondary sedimentary structures.
Secondary sedimentary structures are those which formed after deposition. Such structures form by chemical, physical and biological processes within the sediment. They can be indicators of circumstances after deposition. Some can be used as <a href="way%20up%20structure">way up criteria</a>.
Organic materials in a sediment can leave more traces than just fossils. Preserved tracks and <a href="burrow">burrow</a>s are examples of <a href="trace%20fossil">trace fossil</a>s (also called ichnofossils). Such traces are relatively rare. Most trace fossils are burrows of <a href="molluscs">molluscs</a> or <a href="arthropod">arthropod</a>s. This burrowing is called <a href="bioturbation">bioturbation</a> by sedimentologists. It can be a valuable indicator of the biological and ecological environment that existed after the sediment was deposited. On the other hand, the burrowing activity of organisms can destroy other (primary) structures in the sediment, making a reconstruction more difficult.
Secondary structures can also form by <a href="diagenesis">diagenesis</a> or the formation of a <a href="soil">soil</a> (<a href="pedogenesis">pedogenesis</a>) when a sediment is exposed above the water level. An example of a diagenetic structure common in carbonate rocks is a <a href="stylolite">stylolite</a>. Stylolites are irregular planes where material was dissolved into the pore fluids in the rock. This can result in the precipitation of a certain chemical species producing colouring and staining of the rock, or the formation of <a href="concretion">concretion</a>s. Concretions are roughly concentric bodies with a different composition from the host rock. Their formation can be the result of localized precipitation due to small differences in composition or porosity of the host rock, such as around fossils, inside burrows or around plant roots. In carbonate rocks such as <a href="limestone">limestone</a> or <a href="chalk">chalk</a>, <a href="chert">chert</a> or <a href="flint">flint</a> concretions are common, while terrestrial sandstones sometimes contain iron concretions. Calcite concretions in clay containing angular cavities or cracks are called <a href="septarian%20nodule">septarian concretions</a>.
After deposition, physical processes can <a href="Deformation%20%28science%29">deform</a> the sediment, producing a third class of secondary structures. Density contrasts between different sedimentary layers, such as between sand and clay, can result in <a href="flame%20structure">flame structure</a>s or <a href="load%20cast">load cast</a>s, formed by inverted <a href="diapirism">diapirism</a>. While the clastic bed is still fluid, diapirism can cause a denser upper layer to sink into a lower layer. Sometimes, density contrasts occur or are enhanced when one of the lithologies dehydrates. Clay can be easily compressed as a result of dehydration, while sand retains the same volume and becomes relatively less dense. On the other hand, when the <a href="pore%20fluid%20pressure">pore fluid pressure</a> in a sand layer surpasses a critical point, the sand can break through overlying clay layers and flow through, forming discordant bodies of sedimentary rock called <a href="Clastic%20dike">sedimentary dykes</a>. The same process can form <a href="mud%20volcano">mud volcano</a>es on the surface where they broke through upper layers.
Sedimentary dykes can also be formed in a cold climate where the soil is permanently frozen during a large part of the year. Frost weathering can form cracks in the soil that fill with rubble from above. Such structures can be used as climate indicators as well as way up structures.
Density contrasts can also cause small-scale <a href="fault%20%28geology%29">faulting</a>, even while sedimentation progresses (synchronous-sedimentary faulting). Such faulting can also occur when large masses of non-lithified sediment are deposited on a slope, such as at the front side of a <a href="River%20delta">delta</a> or the <a href="continental%20slope">continental slope</a>. Instabilities in such sediments can result in the deposited material to <a href="slump%20%28geology%29">slump</a>, producing fissures and folding. The resulting structures in the rock are syn-sedimentary <a href="Fold%20%28geology%29">folds</a> and faults, which can be difficult to distinguish from folds and faults formed by <a href="tectonics">tectonic</a> forces acting on lithified rocks.
Depositional environments.
The setting in which a sedimentary rock forms is called the <a href="depositional%20environment">depositional environment</a>. Every environment has a characteristic combination of geologic processes, and circumstances. The type of sediment that is deposited is not only dependent on the sediment that is transported to a place (<a href="Provenance%20%28geology%29">provenance</a>), but also on the environment itself.
A <a href="Oceanic%20basin">marine</a> environment means that the rock was formed in a <a href="sea">sea</a> or <a href="ocean">ocean</a>. Often, a distinction is made between deep and shallow marine environments. Deep marine usually refers to environments more than 200 m below the water surface (including the <a href="abyssal%20plain">abyssal plain</a>). Shallow marine environments exist adjacent to coastlines and can extend to the boundaries of the <a href="continental%20shelf">continental shelf</a>. The water movements in such environments have a generally higher energy than that in deep environments, as <a href="Wind%20wave">wave activity</a> diminishes with depth. This means that coarser sediment particles can be transported and the deposited sediment can be coarser than in deeper environments. When the sediment is transported from the continent, an alternation of <a href="sand">sand</a>, <a href="clay">clay</a> and <a href="silt">silt</a> is deposited. When the continent is far away, the amount of such sediment deposited may be small, and biochemical processes dominate the type of rock that forms. Especially in warm climates, shallow marine environments far offshore mainly see deposition of carbonate rocks. The shallow, warm water is an ideal habitat for many small organisms that build carbonate skeletons. When these organisms die, their skeletons sink to the bottom, forming a thick layer of calcareous mud that may lithify into <a href="limestone">limestone</a>. Warm shallow marine environments also are ideal environments for <a href="coral%20reef">coral reef</a>s, where the sediment consists mainly of the calcareous skeletons of larger organisms.
In deep marine environments, the water current working the sea bottom is small. Only fine particles can be transported to such places. Typically sediments depositing on the ocean floor are fine clay or small skeletons of micro-organisms. At 4 km depth, the solubility of carbonates increases dramatically (the depth zone where this happens is called the <a href="lysocline">lysocline</a>). Calcareous sediment that sinks below the lysocline dissolves; as a result, no limestone can be formed below this depth. Skeletons of micro-organisms formed of <a href="silica">silica</a> (such as <a href="radiolarian">radiolarian</a>s) are not as soluble and are still deposited. An example of a rock formed of silica skeletons is <a href="radiolarite">radiolarite</a>. When the bottom of the sea has a small inclination, for example, at the <a href="continental%20slope">continental slope</a>s, the sedimentary cover can become unstable, causing <a href="turbidity%20current">turbidity current</a>s. Turbidity currents are sudden disturbances of the normally quiet deep marine environment and can cause the near-instantaneous deposition of large amounts of sediment, such as sand and silt. The rock sequence formed by a turbidity current is called a <a href="turbidite">turbidite</a>.
The coast is an environment dominated by wave action. At a <a href="beach">beach</a>, dominantly denser sediment such as sand or <a href="gravel">gravel</a>, often mingled with shell fragments, is deposited, while the silt and clay sized material is kept in mechanical suspension. <a href="Tidal%20flat">Tidal flat</a>s and <a href="shoal">shoal</a>s are places that sometimes dry because of the <a href="tide">tide</a>. They are often cross-cut by <a href="gully">gullies</a>, where the current is strong and the grain size of the deposited sediment is larger. Where rivers enter the body of water, either on a sea or lake coast, <a href="River%20delta">deltas</a> can form. These are large accumulations of sediment transported from the continent to places in front of the mouth of the river. Deltas are dominantly composed of clastic (rather than chemical) sediment.
A continental sedimentary environment is an environment in the interior of a continent. Examples of continental environments are <a href="lagoon">lagoon</a>s, lakes, <a href="swamp">swamp</a>s, <a href="floodplain">floodplain</a>s and <a href="alluvial%20fan">alluvial fan</a>s. In the quiet water of swamps, lakes and lagoons, fine sediment is deposited, mingled with organic material from dead plants and animals. In rivers, the energy of the water is much greater and can transport heavier clastic material. Besides transport by water, sediment can be transported by wind or glaciers. Sediment transported by wind is called <a href="aeolian%20processes">aeolian</a> and is almost always <a href="sorting%20%28sediment%29">very well sorted</a>, while sediment transported by a glacier is called <a href="glacial%20till">glacial till</a> and is characterized by very poor sorting.
Aeolian deposits can be quite striking. The depositional environment of the <a href="Touchet%20Formation">Touchet Formation</a>, located in the <a href="Northwestern%20United%20States">Northwestern United States</a>, had intervening periods of aridity which resulted in a series of <a href="rhythmite">rhythmite</a> layers. Erosional cracks were later infilled with layers of soil material, especially from <a href="aeolian%20processes">aeolian processes</a>. The infilled sections formed vertical inclusions in the horizontally deposited layers, and thus provided evidence of the sequence of events during deposition of the forty-one layers of the formation.
Sedimentary facies.
The kind of rock formed in a particular depositional environment is called its <a href="sedimentary%20facies">sedimentary facies</a>. Sedimentary environments usually exist alongside each other in certain natural successions. A beach, where sand and gravel is deposited, is usually bounded by a deeper marine environment a little offshore, where finer sediments are deposited at the same time. Behind the beach, there can be <a href="dune">dune</a>s (where the dominant deposition is well sorted sand) or a <a href="lagoon">lagoon</a> (where fine clay and organic material is deposited). Every sedimentary environment has its own characteristic deposits. When sedimentary strata accumulate through time, the environment can shift, forming a change in facies in the subsurface at one location. On the other hand, when a rock layer with a certain age is followed laterally, the <a href="lithology">lithology</a> (the type of rock) and facies eventually change.
Facies can be distinguished in a number of ways: the most common are by the lithology (for example: limestone, siltstone or sandstone) or by <a href="fossil">fossil</a> content. <a href="Coral">Coral</a>, for example, only lives in warm and shallow marine environments and fossils of coral are thus typical for shallow marine facies. Facies determined by lithology are called <a href="Facies">lithofacies</a>; facies determined by fossils are <a href="biofacies">biofacies</a>.
Sedimentary environments can shift their geographical positions through time. Coastlines can shift in the direction of the sea when the <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a> drops (<a href="Marine%20regression">regression</a>), when the surface rises (<a href="transgression%20%28geology%29">transgression</a>) due to tectonic forces in the Earth's crust or when a river forms a large <a href="River%20delta">delta</a>. In the subsurface, such geographic shifts of sedimentary environments of the past are recorded in shifts in sedimentary facies. This means that sedimentary facies can change either parallel or perpendicular to an imaginary layer of rock with a fixed age, a phenomenon described by <a href="Walther%27s%20Law">Walther's Law</a>.
The situation in which coastlines move in the direction of the continent is called <a href="transgression%20%28geology%29">transgression</a>. In the case of transgression, deeper marine facies are deposited over shallower facies, a succession called <a href="onlap">onlap</a>. <a href="Marine%20regression">Regression</a> is the situation in which a coastline moves in the direction of the sea. With regression, shallower facies are deposited on top of deeper facies, a situation called <a href="offlap">offlap</a>.
The facies of all rocks of a certain age can be plotted on a map to give an overview of the <a href="palaeogeography">palaeogeography</a>. A sequence of maps for different ages can give an insight in the development of the regional geography.
Sedimentary basins.
Places where large-scale sedimentation takes place are called <a href="sedimentary%20basin">sedimentary basin</a>s. The amount of sediment that can be deposited in a basin depends on the depth of the basin, the so-called "<a href="Accommodation%20%28geology%29">accommodation space</a>". The depth, shape and size of a basin depend on <a href="tectonics">tectonics</a>, movements within the Earth's <a href="lithosphere">lithosphere</a>. Where the lithosphere moves upward (<a href="tectonic%20uplift">tectonic uplift</a>), land eventually rises above sea level and the area becomes a source for new sediment as <a href="erosion">erosion</a> removes material. Where the lithosphere moves downward (<a href="tectonic%20subsidence">tectonic subsidence</a>), a basin forms and sediments are deposited.
A type of basin formed by the moving apart of two pieces of a continent is called a <a href="rift%20basin">rift basin</a>. Rift basins are elongated, narrow and deep basins. Due to divergent movement, the lithosphere is <a href="Deformation%20%28mechanics%29">stretched</a> and thinned, so that the hot <a href="asthenosphere">asthenosphere</a> rises and heats the overlying rift basin. Apart from continental sediments, rift basins normally also have part of their infill consisting of <a href="volcanic%20rock">volcanic deposits</a>. When the basin grows due to continued stretching of the lithosphere, the <a href="rift">rift</a> grows and the sea can enter, forming marine deposits.
When a piece of lithosphere that was heated and stretched cools again, its <a href="density">density</a> rises, causing <a href="isostasy">isostatic</a> subsidence. If this subsidence continues long enough, the basin is called a <a href="sag%20basin">sag basin</a>. Examples of sag basins are the regions along <a href="passive%20margin">passive</a> <a href="continental%20margin">continental margin</a>s, but sag basins can also be found in the interior of continents. In sag basins, the extra weight of the newly deposited sediments is enough to keep the subsidence going in a <a href="virtuous%20circle%20and%20vicious%20circle">vicious circle</a>. The total thickness of the sedimentary infill in a sag basin can thus exceed 10 km.
A third type of basin exists along <a href="convergent%20boundary">convergent plate boundaries</a> – places where one <a href="tectonic%20plate">tectonic plate</a> moves under another into the asthenosphere. The <a href="subduction">subducting</a> plate bends and forms a <a href="fore-arc%20basin">fore-arc basin</a> in front of the overriding plate – an elongated, deep asymmetric basin. Fore-arc basins are filled with deep marine deposits and thick sequences of turbidites. Such infill is called <a href="flysch">flysch</a>. When the convergent movement of the two plates results in <a href="continental%20collision">continental collision</a>, the basin becomes shallower and develops into a <a href="foreland%20basin">foreland basin</a>. At the same time, tectonic uplift forms a <a href="mountain%20belt">mountain belt</a> in the overriding plate, from which large amounts of material are eroded and transported to the basin. Such erosional material of a growing mountain chain is called <a href="molasse">molasse</a> and has either a shallow marine or a continental facies.
At the same time, the growing weight of the mountain belt can cause isostatic subsidence in the area of the overriding plate on the other side to the mountain belt. The basin type resulting from this subsidence is called a <a href="back-arc%20basin">back-arc basin</a> and is usually filled by shallow marine deposits and molasse.
Influence of astronomical cycles.
In many cases facies changes and other lithological features in sequences of sedimentary rock have a cyclic nature. This cyclic nature was caused by cyclic changes in sediment supply and the sedimentary environment. Most of these cyclic changes are caused by <a href="astronomy">astronomic</a> cycles. Short astronomic cycles can be the difference between the <a href="tide">tide</a>s or the <a href="spring%20tide">spring tide</a> every two weeks. On a larger time-scale, cyclic changes in climate and sea level are caused by <a href="Milankovitch%20cycles">Milankovitch cycles</a>: cyclic changes in the orientation and/or position of the Earth's rotational axis and orbit around the Sun. There are a number of Milankovitch cycles known, lasting between 10,000 and 200,000 years.
Relatively small changes in the orientation of the Earth's axis or length of the seasons can be a major influence on the Earth's climate. An example are the <a href="Quaternary%20glaciation">ice ages of the past 2.6 million years</a> (the <a href="Quaternary">Quaternary</a> <a href="Geologic%20time%20scale">period</a>), which are assumed to have been caused by astronomic cycles. Climate change can influence the global sea level (and thus the amount of accommodation space in sedimentary basins) and sediment supply from a certain region. Eventually, small changes in astronomic parameters can cause large changes in sedimentary environment and sedimentation.
Sedimentation rates.
The rate at which sediment is deposited differs depending on the location. A channel in a tidal flat can see the deposition of a few metres of sediment in one day, while on the deep ocean floor each year only a few millimetres of sediment accumulate. A distinction can be made between normal sedimentation and sedimentation caused by catastrophic processes. The latter category includes all kinds of sudden exceptional processes like <a href="Mass%20wasting">mass movements</a>, <a href="rock%20slide">rock slide</a>s or <a href="flood">flood</a>ing. Catastrophic processes can see the sudden deposition of a large amount of sediment at once. In some sedimentary environments, most of the total column of sedimentary rock was formed by catastrophic processes, even though the environment is usually a quiet place. Other sedimentary environments are dominated by normal, ongoing sedimentation.
In many cases, sedimentation occurs slowly. In a <a href="desert">desert</a>, for example, the wind deposits siliciclastic material (sand or silt) in some spots, or catastrophic flooding of a <a href="wadi">wadi</a> may cause sudden deposits of large quantities of detrital material, but in most places eolian erosion dominates. The amount of sedimentary rock that forms is not only dependent on the amount of supplied material, but also on how well the material consolidates. Erosion removes most deposited sediment shortly after deposition.
Stratigraphy.
That new rock layers are above older rock layers is stated in the <a href="Law%20of%20superposition">principle of superposition</a>. There are usually some gaps in the sequence called <a href="unconformity">unconformities</a>. These represent periods where no new sediments were laid down, or when earlier sedimentary layers were raised above sea level and eroded away.
Sedimentary rocks contain important information about the <a href="history%20of%20the%20Earth">history of the Earth</a>. They contain <a href="fossil">fossil</a>s, the preserved remains of ancient <a href="plant">plant</a>s and <a href="animal">animal</a>s. Coal is considered a type of sedimentary rock. The composition of sediments provides us with clues as to the original rock. Differences between successive layers indicate changes to the environment over time. Sedimentary rocks can contain fossils because, unlike most igneous and metamorphic rocks, they form at temperatures and pressures that do not destroy fossil remains.
Provenance.
<a href="Provenance%20%28geology%29">Provenance</a> is the reconstruction of the origin of sediments. All rock exposed at Earth's surface is subjected to physical or chemical <a href="weathering">weathering</a> and broken down into finer grained sediment. All three types of rocks (<a href="igneous%20rock">igneous</a>, sedimentary and <a href="metamorphic%20rock">metamorphic</a> rocks) can be the source of sedimentary detritus. The purpose of sedimentary provenance studies is to reconstruct and interpret the history of sediment from the initial parent rocks at a source area to final detritus at a burial place.
